content.webTitle: View from Brussels: all friends together – or perhaps not

fields.headline: View from Brussels: all friends together – or perhaps not
fields.bodyText: Fricassée de David Cameron was not on the menu – it was quail salad followed by poached veal and with a dessert of strawberries to round things off, since you ask – but if you were the prime minister it surely must have felt like it. Imagine: you’re sat round a table with 27 other reasonably important people, all of whom think you have done something unbelievably stupid and are now determined that you follow through with something unbelievably enormous, very soon. Your sole objective, meanwhile, is to do nothing whatsoever for as long as possible, while pretending you know what you want when actually you don’t because it will be your unfortunate successor who decides. It can’t have been pleasant. Afterwards of course, they all span it – to a point. “This is a sad night for me,” said David Cameron, all stiff upper lip but plainly quite cut up. “I will do everything I can to encourage close relations between Britain and the European Union.” The atmosphere over dinner, declared German chancellor Angela Merkel, was “one of camaraderie. But also ... sadness.” Donald Tusk, the EU council president, insisted all had been “calm and pleasant”. But underneath, it was pretty clear: Britain can have a few months to sort itself out, find a new PM, that kind of stuff, but then it needs to get a move on. There can be no going back, and there will be no special favours. Britain must be bonkers if it thinks it can have single market access without EU migration, said France’s president, François Hollande, bluntly. The commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker, had a dig at British Euroscepticism. Those who “blame Brussels day after day, starting in the morning and finishing in the evening”, he said, who bang on about “Brussels being under the command of Eurocrats and technocrats”, should maybe not be surprised if, at the end of the day, people believe them. It really can’t have been an easy day. The first sighting of the sacrificial victim was in a corridor in the European commission’s gargantuan Berlaymont building, talking animatedly, and to all appearances even amicably, with Juncker. The prime minister and the commission president posed for a brief photo, but did not speak. “Do you regret doing this, prime minister?” cried a voice from the depths of the media crowd. Answer came there none. Diving into the summit proper shortly after, Cameron declared, with commendable if misplaced optimism, that “these countries are our neighbours, our friends, our allies, our partners”, and that he was looking for “the closest possible relationship”. Good luck with that one, prime minister. Among others early to the party, German chancellor Angela Merkel blinked, wagged her finger – the one she pulls the strings with – and reminded everyone it was important to still see Britain “as a friend”. Good luck with that one, chancellor. François Hollande said the union had no time to lose. “Europe,” the French president insisted, “continues. History doesn’t stop.” But since his story, as the least popular leader France has ever had, will very definitely stop about this time next year when he faces a very nasty-looking election, nobody took much notice. Pretty much every other leader said, in actually rather a British kind of way, that London just needed to jolly well get a move on, please, because this really was not good enough. The Luxembourg prime minister, Xavier Bettel, made it plain for the digital age. “We are not on Facebook, where things are complicated,” he said. “We are married or divorced. Not something in between.” Britain did, though, find an unlikely ally in the fiery Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, himself no stranger to bitter and protracted face-offs with the beasts of Brussels. Tsipras said this whole thing was thoroughly predictable, because Europe was thoroughly undemocratic. The EU, he said, needs to “replace austerity with growth, division with convergence, unemployment with decent jobs and endless negotiations behind closed doors with transparency and democracy”. Good luck with that one, prime minister. Donald Tusk, the council president who is chairing the summit, did, though, say he was planning a special meeting of the EU leaders – without Cameron, clearly – in Bratislava in September, to chart a path through the wreckage. And Germany, France and Italy came up with something lengthy in a royal blue folder about boosting EU cooperation on security and stimulating economic growth and youth employment. So there’s hope. After that, it was down to business. Not Brexit business, regrettably: “accelerated practical co-operation” with Nato, investment in the western Balkans, competitiveness, cross-border portability of e-commerce, migration, relations with Libya. Before last Friday, Cameron, sat at the end of the table in his shirt sleeves, might have been quite interested in some of this. Presumably not now. Not difficult, though, to imagine the ambience. These were the people, after all, with whom he hammered out, over some long, long nights all those centuries ago in February, that “reformed relationship” deal between Britain and the EU – the one he was supposed to use to keep Britain in the EU, but barely mentioned during the referendum campaign. The day began, as these meetings surely now will for untold aeons to come, with a chill smile, an embrace, a brief, brave pretence that in spite of everything, we might still stay friends – and the sudden, sinking realisation that that’s definitely not going to happen. Divorces are like that. First up, in the European parliament, was an avuncular Juncker, greeting Nigel Farage with a kiss. Then a slap. “Why are you even here?” he shot. Finally presented with incontrovertible proof that Britain’s semi-detached, not to say bolshy attitude down the years masked – as they had suspected all along – full-blown perfidy, MEPs seethed with barely contained fury. “Shame on you,” Manfred Weber, a good friend of Merkel, hurled at Farage. “The worst among the liars.” Guy Verhofstadt, a mild-mannered former prime minister of Belgium, waded into the fray, taking a thinly veiled swing at Boris Johnson: much of this could be put down, Verhofstadt said, to “the selfishness of one man, prepared to do anything to become prime minister of the UK”. But there was warm applause – indeed, a standing ovation – for an emotional Scottish MEP, Alyn Smith. “We will need cool heads and warm hearts,” he urged his fellow parliamentarians. “But please, remember this: Scotland did not let you down. I beg you, do not let Scotland down now.” With appeals to their European hearts like that, it did not take long for everyone to conclude the only thing they could possibly do under the circs was immediately pass a motion calling for Britain to begin formal negotiations on leaving the European Union “as soon as possible”. And so, finally, to dinner, Cameron’s chance to “explain Britain’s position”. “I want the exit process,” he said, “to be as constructive as possible.” Good luck with that one, prime minister.
